nodes.bodyText: What version of common is this? Looks very old
Good catch.  I'm going to point this to 0.0.+.  Using 0.0. to ensure that no one tries to ship one of these.
but why are we not using the latest? (3.0.4)
I thought 0.0 made it clear that this isn't intended to be used... in any production scenario.
I'm not clear on what is happening here?

nodes.bodyText: Does groovy coerce this to 0?
I assume you're referring to type coercion, but not sure i'm following in this case.  getLatestPatchVersion returns an integer or it throws an exception and would fail the script.

I assume you're referring to type coercion, but not sure i'm following in this case. getLatestPatchVersion returns an integer or it throws an exception and would fail the script.

I'm just wondering about the case where that file is empty or doesn't exist.  We implicitly accept that earlier.  I'd rather fail there.
I didn't write that code, and i'd like to avoid refactoring something that doesn't have any record of being broken.

explode if you can't find it, pls, and tell people why (this environment variable and this property were both empty, could not find access token to talk to foo).  Bonus points, include information about what scopes and organizations that access token needs to be able to work.  You're new and you're running this.  You should be able to remediate based on the output.

@@ -1,4 +1,42 @@
-apply plugin: 'java-library'
+plugins {
+    id 'java-library'
+    id 'maven-publish'
+}
+
+apply from: '../common/versioning/version_tasks.gradle'
+
+project.ext.vstsUsername = System.getenv("ENV_VSTS_MVN_ANDROIDCOMMON_USERNAME") != null ? System.getenv("ENV_VSTS_MVN_ANDROIDCOMMON_USERNAME") : project.findProperty("vstsUsername")
+project.ext.vstsPassword = System.getenv("ENV_VSTS_MVN_ANDROIDCOMMON_ACCESSTOKEN") != null ? System.getenv("ENV_VSTS_MVN_ANDROIDCOMMON_ACCESSTOKEN") : project.findProperty("vstsMavenAccessToken")

nodes.bodyText: This seems to do the same thing in both cases.  Am I missing something?  I am.  There's an extra common if the file exists.
I think so... the path is different.

Yup.  So one will cover common as part of android-complete, and the other as part of common.  I wonder that this shouldn't be parameterized to work with all the other packages.  But a comment would be nice.

I was consider writing a document to cover gradle project composability.  To be honest I think the design of this can be improved.  Again since the same code is in multiple projects i'll take this a feedback for my next update of everything referenced by Android-complete.  Would be interested to see an example of what you're thinking about in terms of parameterization.
So if this becomes a reusable activity that you can just add to your flow, then $rootDir/$versionFile, I would thing, where versionFile is in the workflow instance definition.
Yep.  We can design something better here.  Sounds like a fun hackathon project.
